messages.content: Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
How do I check the status of my trade mark application?

You can check the status of your trade mark application by visiting our electronic online system, IPOS Digital Hub (IDH) at https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg and conducting a search using the application number generated upon submission of your application form.
For information on how to manage your trade mark, for example amend trade mark details, change ownership, renew or cancel your trade mark, please refer to https://www.ipos.gov.sg/about-ip/trade-marks/managing-trade-marks.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
how to renew the trademark?

You are able to renew the trademark for another period of 10 years by filing Form TM 19 with the fee of $440.00 on or 6 months before the expiry date. The Form TM 19 can be filed online at https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg.

At this portal, you will need to create a new account when you log in with your SingPass if you have not done so.

Once, you have created the account successfully, click ‘Forms’ and proceed to click the description of Form TM 19. You will need to key in the trademark number at Part 1.2 of Form TM 19. Payment online will be made either by credit card or Internet banking.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
How can I find a specific patent information registered in Singapore?

Please note that you are able to conduct a patent search online free as follows:https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg >>> Search >>> Basic Search >>> Search Criteria (Key in the patent number) >>> Select (Patent Application No) >>> Search.The result will be at the bottom of the page. You may proceed to click the patent number in red for full detail.
Hope you find the above information useful and please feel free to contact us if you require further assistance.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
How can I change the proprietor's address recorded with the trade mark?

If there is a change in the company address, please file Form CM 2. This form can be filed online free of charge at https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg. You will need to login and create an account if you have not done so. Once you have login successfully, click ‘Forms’ and further click the description of the Form CM 2.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
How can I apply for a trade mark in Singapore?

A trade mark is a sign that you can use to distinguish your business’ goods or services from those of other traders. A trade mark must also be distinctive and capable of distinguishing the goods/services of the owner from similar goods/services of other traders. This sign can be any letter, word, name, signature, numeral, device, brand, heading, label, ticket, shape, colour, aspect of packaging or a combination of these.To apply for trade mark registration in Singapore, you will have to file Form TM 4, together with the prevailing fees via online submission on our IPOS Digital Hub platform at https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg) for each trade mark.
The applicant must have Singpass or Corppass to create an IPOS Digital Hub account for transacting with IPOS and an address for service in Singapore for the filing of any trade mark forms. Alternatively, applicants may enlist the help of an agent to transact on their behalf.
You may wish to conduct a check in our online database (free of charge) prior to making your trade mark application to see if a mark similar to yours has already been registered with the following steps:At https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg under ‘Search’, click ‘TM Similar Mark Search’To conduct a more detailed search on the descriptions/specifications of the goods and services, you may wish to carry out the following:
At https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg under ‘Search’, click ‘TM Goods/Services Search’
For more information about trade marks, you can refer to our website at https://www.ipos.gov.sg and our Trade Marks Infopack here [link: https://www.ipos.gov.sg/docs/default-source/resources-library/trade-marks/infopacks/tm-infopack-11oct2023.pdf].
For more information on Singpass/Corppass, please visit www.singpass.gov.sg or www.corppass.gov.sg.
For more information on IPOS Digital Hub account creation and management, please refer to https://www.ipos.gov.sg/eservices
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
After the Trade Mark Applicant files his Statutory Declaration (SD), what must the Opponent do?

The Opponent can choose not to reply to the Applicant's SD, if he does not have anything new to say in response to the Applicant's evidence. The opposition will proceed to a Pre-Hearing Review.
However, the Opponent may also choose to file his evidence in reply to the Applicant's SD. If so, this has to be done within the deadline specified by the Registrar. [R 31A] After this, the opposition will proceed to a Pre-Hearing Review.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
How can I participate in the Intellectual Property (IP) Clinics?
You can visit us here and register for an Intellectual Property (IP) Business Clinic or Legal Clinic.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
What is a priority claim?

Singapore, like many countries, allows priority claims to be made in a patent application. If an applicant has an application filed earlier in a Paris Convention Treaty or a World Trade Organization (WTO) member country (other than Singapore), the applicant may claim priority from this first-filed application, provided the Singapore registration is filed within 12 months from the date of the first filing.

Similarly, an application which is first filed in Singapore can be used to claim priority in a corresponding application filed in a Paris Convention country or a World Trade Organization member country, provided that the corresponding application is filed within 12 months from the date of the first-filed Singapore application.

Applicants have two more months after the 12-month period to file the Singapore patent application and claim priority, based on an earlier application filed in a Paris Convention or World Trade Organization member state if they can show that they missed the initial 12-month period either unintentionally, or despite showing due care.

Other requirements include the payment of a fee and the furnishing of Patents Form 57 within a prescribed period if such a restoration is sought in a patent application. For the list of parties to Paris Convention and members of the World Trade Organization, please refer to the WIPO (World Intellectual Property Organisation) website and the WTO website.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
What is the difference between a lawyer and a registered patent agent?

In general, these are two separate professions but responsibilities overlap. It is common for lawyers and patent agents to work together on patent matters. In Singapore, some lawyers are also registered patent agents.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
Do I need a lawyer to represent me in contentious proceedings?

It is not mandatory for you to engage a lawyer and you may certainly represent yourself. However, contentious proceedings tend to be complex and are governed by strict formal pleading and evidential requirements. We therefore strongly recommend that you consider obtaining professional assistance, whether it be that of a suitably qualified agent or lawyer.
If you would like to seek preliminary advice on your rights before you decide on your next course of action, IPOS conducts weekly complimentary IP Legal Clinics for Singapore citizens/Permanent resident and Singapore registered businesses. For more information on IP Legal Clinics, please see https://www.ipos.gov.sg/eservices/ip-clinics.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
if the applicant is a company registered in Singapore, does it need to be file an national security clearance application when filing in the foreign country without filing in Singapore?

While it is not mandatory to apply for patent protection in Singapore first before seeking protection overseas, a national security clearance may be required. Section 34 of the Singapore Patents Act <https://sso.agc.gov.sg/Act/PA1994#pr34>  states that any person resident in Singapore is required to obtain a written authorisation from IPOS before the person files or causes to be filed outside Singapore an application for a patent for the same invention.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
If I commission an artist to design a piece of artwork, and use that to be printed on a shirt. Would I be in any legal trouble?

Please note that the ownership of the copyright of the work will belong to the creator unless stated otherwise in your agreement and contract.
For your information, the ownership of the copyright can be assigned or transferred,  if both parties are agreeable to the terms which is a private agreement or contract between the parties.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
What is the difference between sound recordings and musical works?

Sound recordings are generally musical works in a format of vinyl record, CD or digital audio file.Musical works refer to the original musical composition, including the melody, harmony and lyrics (if applicable)
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
How can I manage changes to the ownership of a trade mark?

A change of ownership of a trade mark application which is pending or a registered trade mark may be recorded in the Register. An application for the recordal of the assignment should be made on Form CM8 at the prevailing fee via IPOS Digital Hub at https://digitalhub.ipos.gov.sg.
IPOS will not issue a certificate to reflect the change of ownership. If you wish to obtain a certified copy containing the most up to date trade mark details or a certified extract containing the history of change of ownership, please file Form CM12 and pay the prevailing fees through IPOS Digital Hub.
For more information about trade mark transfer of ownership, please refer to https://www.ipos.gov.sg/about-ip/trade-marks/managing-trade-marks/maintaining-trade-marks#maintain-your-singapore-trade-mark.
Marv is a factual chatbot that is also sarcastic.
I run a music and dance school. Do i need to purchase a copyright license to teach my students in classes?

It depends on what materials you use in your classes.
Copyright protection grants a copyright owner of a work the exclusive right to prohibit others from using that work. This means that, if you want to use another person’s copyright-protected works (e.g., teaching from sheet music or playing recorded music), you need to obtain the right to do to. You can either obtain permission directly from the copyright owner, or obtain a licence from the relevant collective management organisation (“CMO”) managing the relevant rights in those works. A CMO is a private entity appointed by copyright owners to manage the licensing of their copyright in a collective manner for efficiency both for copyright owners and users.
However, if you use only public domain works in your classes, you do not need to obtain permission or a licence. You may use public domain works freely. These are works in which copyright has expired (e.g., the copyright in musical works expires 70 years after the death of their authors). This would include sheet music written by composers who have died more than 70 years ago.
Even where a particular work has entered the public domain, there can still be copyright protection over sound recordings of that work being performed. In such a situation, the musical work itself may be in the public domain and free to use (e.g., the sheet music) but the specific sound recording of a particular musician performing that work may still be copyright-protected (i.e., you would need to obtain permission or a licence to play that specific sound recording in your class).
You may refer to the Copyright Infopack for more details on the above.
